Multistep methods

In Runge–Kutta methods we start at uiu_iui​ to find ui+1{u}_{i+1}ui+1​, taking multiple fff-evaluations (stages) to achieve high accuracy. In contrast, multistep methods boost accuracy by employing more of the history of the solution, taking information from the recent past. For the discussion in this and following sections, we introduce the shorthand notation

fi=f(ti,ui).f_i = f(t_i,u_i).fi​=f(ti​,ui​).
(6.6.1)
Definition 6.6.1 (Multistep method for IVPs)

A kkk-step multistep (or linear multistep) method is given by the difference equation

ui+1=ak−1ui+⋯+a0ui−k+1+h(bkfi+1+⋯+b0fi−k+1),\begin{split} u_{i+1} &= a_{k-1}u_i + \cdots + a_0 u_{i-k+1} \qquad \\ & \qquad + h ( b_kf_{i+1} + \cdots + b_0 f_{i-k+1}), \end{split}ui+1​​=ak−1​ui​+⋯+a0​ui−k+1​+h(bk​fi+1​+⋯+b0​fi−k+1​),​
(6.6.2)

where the aja_jaj​ and the bjb_jbj​ are constants. If bk=0b_k=0bk​=0, the method is explicit; otherwise, it is implicit.

The quantities uuu and fff in (6.6.2) are shown as scalars, but in general they can be vectors.

In order to use (6.6.2) as a numerical method, we iterate through i=k−1,…,n−1i=k-1,\ldots,n-1i=k−1,…,n−1. The value u0u_0u0​ is determined by the initial condition, but we also need some way of generating the starting values

u1=α1,…uk−1=αk−1.u_1=\alpha_1, \quad \ldots \quad u_{k-1}=\alpha_{k-1}.u1​=α1​,…uk−1​=αk−1​.
(6.6.3)

In practice the starting values are often found using an RK formula.[1]

The difference formula (6.6.2) defines ui+1{u}_{i+1}ui+1​ in terms of known values of the solution and its derivative from the past. In the explicit case with bk=0b_k=0bk​=0, Equation (6.6.2) immediately gives a formula for the unknown quantity ui+1{u}_{i+1}ui+1​ in terms of values at time level tit_iti​ and earlier. Thus only one new evaluation of fff is needed to make a time step, provided that we store the recent history.

For an implicit method, however, bk≠0b_k\neq 0bk​=0 and (6.6.2) has the form

ui+1−hbkf(ti+1,ui+1)=F(ui,ui−1,…,ui−k+1). {u}_{i+1} - hb_kf(t_{i+1},{u}_{i+1}) = F(u_i,u_{i-1},\ldots,u_{i-k+1}).ui+1​−hbk​f(ti+1​,ui+1​)=F(ui​,ui−1​,…,ui−k+1​).
(6.6.4)

Now the unknown ui+1{u}_{i+1}ui+1​ that we seek appears inside the function fff. In general this equation is a nonlinear rootfinding problem for ui+1{u}_{i+1}ui+1​ and is not solvable in a finite number of steps by a formula. The implementation of both explicit and implicit multistep formulas is discussed in detail in Implementation of multistep methods.

As with RK formulas, a multistep method is entirely specified by the values of a few constants. Table 6.6.1 and Table 6.6.2 present some of the most well-known and important formulas. The Adams–Bashforth (AB) methods are explicit, while Adams–Moulton (AM) and backward differentiation formulas (BD) are implicit. The tables also list the methods’ order of accuracy, to be defined shortly. We adopt the convention of referring to a multistep method by appending its order of accuracy to a two-letter name abbreviation, e.g., the AB3 method.

6.6.1Generating polynomials¶

An alternative description of a multistep method is the generating polynomials

ρ(z)=zk−ak−1zk−1−⋯−a0,σ(z)=bkzk+bk−1zk−1+⋯+b0.\begin{split} \rho(z) &= z^k - a_{k-1} z^{k-1} - \cdots - a_0,\\ \sigma(z) &= b_k z^k + b_{k-1}z^{k-1} + \cdots + b_0. \end{split}ρ(z)σ(z)​=zk−ak−1​zk−1−⋯−a0​,=bk​zk+bk−1​zk−1+⋯+b0​.​
(6.6.5)

For example, the AB3 method is completely specified by

ρ(z)=z3−z2,σ(z)=112(23z2−16z+5). \rho(z) = z^3-z^2, \qquad \sigma(z) = \tfrac{1}{12}(23z^2-16z+5).ρ(z)=z3−z2,σ(z)=121​(23z2−16z+5).
(6.6.6)
Observation 6.6.1

Let ρ and σ be the generating polynomials of a multistep method. Then:

  1. The polynomial ρ(z)\rho(z)ρ(z) is monic (i.e., its leading term has a unit coefficient).
  2. The degree of ρ is the number of steps kkk.
  3. The degree of σ(z)\sigma(z)σ(z) is kkk for an implicit method and less than kkk for an explicit method.

The connection between the generating polynomials and the numerical method requires a little abstraction. Let Z\mathcal{Z}Z be a forward-shift operator, so that, for example, Zti=ti+1\mathcal{Z} t_i = t_{i+1}Zti​=ti+1​, Z3ui−1=ui+2\mathcal{Z}^3 u_{i-1} = u_{i+2}Z3ui−1​=ui+2​, and so on. With this, the difference formula (6.6.2) can be written concisely as

ρ(Z)ui−k+1=hσ(Z)fi−k+1. \rho(\mathcal{Z}) u_{i-k+1} = h \sigma(\mathcal{Z}) f_{i-k+1}.ρ(Z)ui−k+1​=hσ(Z)fi−k+1​.
(6.6.7)

6.6.2Truncation and global error¶

The definition of local truncation error is easily extended to multistep methods.

Definition 6.6.2 (LTE and order of accuracy for a multistep IVP method)

For the multistep formula defined by (6.6.2), the local truncation error is

τi+1(h)=u^(ti+1)−ak−1u^(ti)−⋯−a0u^(ti−k+1)h−[bkf(ti+1,u^(ti+1))+⋯+b0f(ti−k+1,u^(ti−k+1))]. \tau_{i+1}(h) = \frac{\hat{u}(t_{i+1}) - a_{k-1}\hat{u}(t_i) - \cdots - a_0 \hat{u}(t_{i-k+1})}{h} - \bigl[ b_kf(t_{i+1},\hat{u}(t_{i+1})) + \cdots + b_0f(t_{i-k+1},\hat{u}(t_{i-k+1})) \bigr].τi+1​(h)=hu^(ti+1​)−ak−1​u^(ti​)−⋯−a0​u^(ti−k+1​)​−[bk​f(ti+1​,u^(ti+1​))+⋯+b0​f(ti−k+1​,u^(ti−k+1​))].
(6.6.8)

If the local truncation error satisfies τi+1(h)=O(hp)\tau_{i+1}(h)=O(h^p)τi+1​(h)=O(hp), then ppp is the order of accuracy of the formula. If p>0p>0p>0, the method is consistent.

Example 6.6.1

The first-order Adams–Moulton method is also known as backward Euler, because its difference equation is

ui+1=ui+hfi+1, {u}_{i+1} = u_i + hf_{i+1},ui+1​=ui​+hfi+1​,
(6.6.9)

which is equivalent to a backward-difference approximation to u′(ti+1)u'(t_{i+1})u′(ti+1​). AM1 is characterized by ρ(z)=z−1\rho(z) = z-1ρ(z)=z−1 and σ(z)=z\sigma(z) = zσ(z)=z.

To derive the LTE, we use the definition:

hτi+1(h)=u^(ti+1)−u^(ti)−hf(ti+1,u^(ti+1))=u^(ti)+hu^′(ti)+h22u^′′(ti)+O(h3)−u^(ti)−hu^′(ti+1)=hu^′(ti)+h22u^′′(ti)+O(h3)−h[u^′(ti)+hu^′′(ti)+O(h2)]=−h22u^′′(ti)+O(h3).\begin{split} h\tau_{i+1}(h) &= \hat{u}(t_{i+1}) - \hat{u}(t_i) - hf\bigl(t_{i+1},\hat{u}(t_{i+1})\bigr) \\ &= \hat{u}(t_i) + h\hat{u}'(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^3) - \hat{u}(t_i) -h \hat{u}'(t_{i+1}) \\ &= h\hat{u}'(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^3) - h[\hat{u}'(t_i) + h\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^2)]\\ &= - \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^3). \end{split}hτi+1​(h)​=u^(ti+1​)−u^(ti​)−hf(ti+1​,u^(ti+1​))=u^(ti​)+hu^′(ti​)+2h2​u^′′(ti​)+O(h3)−u^(ti​)−hu^′(ti+1​)=hu^′(ti​)+2h2​u^′′(ti​)+O(h3)−h[u^′(ti​)+hu^′′(ti​)+O(h2)]=−2h2​u^′′(ti​)+O(h3).​
(6.6.10)

Thus τi+1(h)=O(h)\tau_{i+1}(h)=O(h)τi+1​(h)=O(h) and AM1 (backward Euler) is a first-order method.

Example 6.6.2

The AB2 method has the formula

ui+1=ui+h(32fi−12fi−1). {u}_{i+1} = u_i + h\left(\frac{3}{2} f_i - \frac{1}{2} f_{i-1} \right).ui+1​=ui​+h(23​fi​−21​fi−1​).
(6.6.11)

The generating polynomials are ρ(z)=z2−z\rho(z)=z^2-zρ(z)=z2−z and σ(z)=(3z−1)/2\sigma(z) = (3z-1)/2σ(z)=(3z−1)/2. We find that the method is second order from the LTE:

hτi+1(h)=u^(ti+1)−u^(ti)−h[32f(ti,u^(ti))−12f(ti−1,u^(ti−1))]=u^(ti)+hu^′(ti)+h22u^′′(ti)+h36u^′′′(ti)+O(h4)−u^(ti)−3h2u^′(ti)+h2[u^′(ti)−hu^′′(ti)+h22u^′′′(ti)+O(h3)]=5h312u^′′′(ti)+O(h4),\begin{split} h\tau_{i+1}(h) & = \hat{u}(t_{i+1}) - \hat{u}(t_i) - h\left[ \frac{3}{2}f(t_i,\hat{u}(t_i)) - \frac{1}{2}f(t_{i-1},\hat{u}(t_{i-1})) \right] \\ & = \hat{u}(t_i) + h\hat{u}'(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + \frac{h^3}{6}\hat{u}'''(t_i) + O(h^4) \\ & \qquad - \hat{u}(t_i) - \frac{3h}{2}\hat{u}'(t_i) \\ &\qquad + \frac{h}{2} \bigl[\hat{u}'(t_i) - h\hat{u}''(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}'''(t_i) + O(h^3)\bigr] \\ & = \frac{5h^3}{12}\hat{u}'''(t_i) + O(h^4), \end{split}hτi+1​(h)​=u^(ti+1​)−u^(ti​)−h[23​f(ti​,u^(ti​))−21​f(ti−1​,u^(ti−1​))]=u^(ti​)+hu^′(ti​)+2h2​u^′′(ti​)+6h3​u^′′′(ti​)+O(h4)−u^(ti​)−23h​u^′(ti​)+2h​[u^′(ti​)−hu^′′(ti​)+2h2​u^′′′(ti​)+O(h3)]=125h3​u^′′′(ti​)+O(h4),​
(6.6.12)

so that τi+1(h)=O(h2)\tau_{i+1}(h)=O(h^2)τi+1​(h)=O(h2).

Although we will not present the analysis, the main conclusion for the multistep methods in this section is the same as for one-step methods.

Observation 6.6.2

The global error of each method in Table 6.6.1 and Table 6.6.2 converges at the same order as the local truncation error.

6.6.3Derivation of the formulas¶

Where do coefficients like those in Table 6.6.1 come from? There are different ways to answer that question, but Adams and BD methods have distinctive stories to tell. The derivation of Adams methods begins with the observation that

u^(ti+1)=u^(ti)+∫titi+1u^′(t) dt=u^(ti)+∫titi+1f(t,u^(t)) dt. \hat{u}(t_{i+1}) = \hat{u}(t_i) + \int_{t_i}^{t_{i+1}} \hat{u}'(t) \, dt = \hat{u}(t_i) + \int_{t_i}^{t_{i+1}} f\bigl(t,\hat{u}(t)\bigr) \, dt.u^(ti+1​)=u^(ti​)+∫ti​ti+1​​u^′(t)dt=u^(ti​)+∫ti​ti+1​​f(t,u^(t))dt.
(6.6.13)

As a result, a kkk-step Adams method always has ρ(z)=zk−zk−1\rho(z)=z^k-z^{k-1}ρ(z)=zk−zk−1. While the integrand above is unknown over the interval of integration, we can approximate it by a polynomial interpolant of the historical values of fff. That polynomial can be integrated analytically, leading to a derivation of the coefficients b0,…,bkb_0,\ldots,b_kb0​,…,bk​.

Example 6.6.3

Let’s derive a one-step AM method using the two values (ti,fi)(t_i,f_i)(ti​,fi​) and (ti+1,fi+1)(t_{i+1},f_{i+1})(ti+1​,fi+1​). The interpolating polynomial is the linear function

p(t)=fiti+1−tti+1−ti+fi+1t−titi+1−ti.p(t) = f_i\frac{t_{i+1}-t}{t_{i+1}-t_i} + f_{i+1}\frac{t-t_i}{t_{i+1}-t_i}.p(t)=fi​ti+1​−ti​ti+1​−t​+fi+1​ti+1​−ti​t−ti​​.
(6.6.14)

Things become a little easier with the change of variable s=t−tis=t-t_is=t−ti​ and applying h=ti+1−tih=t_{i+1}-t_ih=ti+1​−ti​:

∫titi+1p(t) dt=∫0hp(ti+s) ds=h−1∫0h[(h−s)fi+sfi+1] ds=h2(fi+fi+1).\int_{t_i}^{t_{i+1}} p(t) \, d t = \int_0^h p(t_i+s) \, d s = h^{-1} \int_0^h [ (h-s)f_i + s f_{i+1} ]\, d s = \frac{h}{2}(f_i + f_{i+1}).∫ti​ti+1​​p(t)dt=∫0h​p(ti​+s)ds=h−1∫0h​[(h−s)fi​+sfi+1​]ds=2h​(fi​+fi+1​).
(6.6.15)

Hence σ(z)=12z+12\sigma(z)=\tfrac{1}{2}z + \tfrac{1}{2}σ(z)=21​z+21​. Like the trapezoid formula for a definite integral, AM2 computes the exact integral of a piecewise linear interpolant, and it often goes by the trapezoid name as well.

In AB methods, the interpolating polynomial has degree k−1k-1k−1, which means that its interpolation error is O(hk)O(h^k)O(hk). Upon integrating we get a local error of O(hk+1)O(h^{k+1})O(hk+1), which reduces to a global error of O(hk)O(h^k)O(hk). The AM interpolating polynomial is one degree larger, so its order of accuracy is one higher for the same number of steps.

The idea behind backward differentiation formulas is complementary to that for Adams: Interpolate solution values ui+1,…,ui−k+1{u}_{i+1},\ldots,u_{i-k+1}ui+1​,…,ui−k+1​ by a polynomial qqq, and then, motivated by f(t,u^)=u^′(t)f(t,\hat{u})=\hat{u}'(t)f(t,u^)=u^′(t), set

fi+1=q′(ti+1). f_{i+1} =q'(t_{i+1}).fi+1​=q′(ti+1​).
(6.6.16)

The quantity q′(ti+1)q'(t_{i+1})q′(ti+1​) can be approximated by a finite difference of the past solution values, leading to the coefficients of ρ(z)\rho(z)ρ(z) and σ(z)=bkzk\sigma(z)=b_k z^kσ(z)=bk​zk.

Example 6.6.4

Consulting Table 5.4.2, we find the finite-difference approximation

q′(ti+1)≈1h(32ui+1−2ui+12ui−1),q'(t_{i+1}) \approx \frac{1}{h} \left( \frac{3}{2} u_{i+1} - 2 u_i + \frac{1}{2} u_{i-1} \right),q′(ti+1​)≈h1​(23​ui+1​−2ui​+21​ui−1​),
(6.6.17)

from which we get

hfi+1=32ui+1−2ui+12ui−1.h f_{i+1} = \frac{3}{2} u_{i+1} - 2 u_i + \frac{1}{2} u_{i-1}.hfi+1​=23​ui+1​−2ui​+21​ui−1​.
(6.6.18)

Rearranging and Normalizing by the coefficient of ui+1u_{i+1}ui+1​ gives ρ(z)=z2+43z−13\rho(z)=z^2 + \tfrac{4}{3}z - \tfrac{1}{3}ρ(z)=z2+34​z−31​ and σ(z)=23z2\sigma(z) = \tfrac{2}{3}z^2σ(z)=32​z2, which is the BD2 method.

  1. ✍ For each method, write out the generating polynomials ρ(z)\rho(z)ρ(z) and σ(z)\sigma(z)σ(z).

    (a) AM2, (b) AB2, (c) BD2, (d) AM3, (e) AB3.

  2. ✍ Write out by hand an equation that defines the first solution value u1u_1u1​ produced by AM1 (backward Euler) for each IVP. (Reminder: This is an implicit formula.)

    (a) u′=−2tu,0≤t≤2,u0=2,h=0.2u' = -2t u, \quad 0 \le t \le 2, \quad u_0 = 2, \quad h = 0.2u′=−2tu,0≤t≤2,u0​=2,h=0.2

    (b) u′=u+t,0≤t≤1,u0=2,h=0.1u' = u + t, \quad 0 \le t \le 1, \quad u_0 = 2, \quad h = 0.1u′=u+t,0≤t≤1,u0​=2,h=0.1

    (c) (1+x3)uu′=x2,0≤x≤3,u0=1,,h=0.5(1+x^3)uu' = x^2,\quad 0 \le x \le 3, \quad u_0=1, , \quad h = 0.5(1+x3)uu′=x2,0≤x≤3,u0​=1,,h=0.5

  3. ✍ Do the preceding exercise for AM2 (trapezoid) instead of backward Euler.

  4. ✍ For each method, find the leading term in the local truncation error using (6.6.8).

    (a) AM2, (b) AB2, (c) BD2.

  5. ✍/ ⌨ For each method, find the leading term in the local truncation error using (6.6.8). (Computer algebra is recommended.)

    (a) AM3, (b) AB3, (c) BD4.

  6. ✍ A formula for the quadratic polynomial interpolant through the points (s1,y1)(s_1,y_1)(s1​,y1​), (s2,y2)(s_2,y_2)(s2​,y2​), and (s3,y3)(s_3,y_3)(s3​,y3​) is

    p(x)=(x−s2)(x−s3)(s1−s2)(s1−s3) y1+(x−s1)(x−s3)(s2−s1)(s2−s3) y2+(x−s1)(x−s2)(s3−s1)(s3−s2) y3.p(x) = \frac{(x-s_2)(x-s_3)}{(s_1-s_2)(s_1-s_3)}\,y_1 + \frac{(x-s_1)(x-s_3)}{(s_2-s_1)(s_2-s_3)}\,y_2 + \frac{(x-s_1)(x-s_2)}{(s_3-s_1)(s_3-s_2)}\,y_3.p(x)=(s1​−s2​)(s1​−s3​)(x−s2​)(x−s3​)​y1​+(s2​−s1​)(s2​−s3​)(x−s1​)(x−s3​)​y2​+(s3​−s1​)(s3​−s2​)(x−s1​)(x−s2​)​y3​.
    (6.6.19)

    (a) Use (6.6.13) and a polynomial interpolant through three points to derive the coefficients of the AM3 method.

    (b) Use (6.6.16) and a polynomial interpolant through three points to derive the coefficients of the BD2 method.

  7. ✍ By doing series expansion about the point z=1z=1z=1, show for BD2 that

    ρ(z)σ(z)−log⁡(z−1)=O((z−1)3).\frac{\rho(z)}{\sigma(z)} - \log(z-1) = O\bigl( (z-1)^3 \bigr).σ(z)ρ(z)​−log(z−1)=O((z−1)3).
    (6.6.20)

  8. ✍/ ⌨ By doing series expansion about the point z=1z=1z=1, show for AB3 and AM3 that

    ρ(z)σ(z)−log⁡(z−1)=O((z−1)4).\frac{\rho(z)}{\sigma(z)} - \log(z-1) = O\bigl( (z-1)^4 \bigr).σ(z)ρ(z)​−log(z−1)=O((z−1)4).

    (Computer algebra is recommended.)

Footnotes¶

  1. If we must use an RK method to start anyway, why bother with multistep formulas at all? The answer is that multistep methods can be more efficient in some problems, even at the same order of accuracy.
